"The movement is what we‚Äôre most concerned with. But the artwork is obviously a result of the protests, and the protests are a result of the historical injustices.‚Äù
- Randolph Belle, spokesperson for the Black Cultural Zone.  

https://t.co/4XKMRTX9Dv https://t.co/9UBXqYNsuH

@EvanWebeck @LibbySchaaf Yes, an effort to preserve, document, and archive many of the works created is underway, led by the Black Cultural Zone. Artists, tenants, landlords, or building owners should contact info@blackculturalzone.org for more details. If we can assist, contact feedback@museumca.org.

We miss seeing you in our galleries, so we're bringing our galleries to you! Explore the history of the Black Power movements in California in an online version of our exhibition Black Power. #blacklivesmatter https://t.co/tXlyPloarz https://t.co/HPHf6sftRI

If artists, tenants, landlords, or building owners have questions or information about the artwork, please contact info@blackculturalzone.org. If we can assist, please contact feedback@museumca.org. We look forward to sharing more information as these efforts progress.
At the right time, we hope to be one of many groups that are committed to presenting and archiving the artwork and documenting the stories, in collaboration with the artists.

At this stage, the organizations and groups of artists are coordinating logistics to ensure that the artwork is safely cared for and stored, when it comes down, and that artists are contacted for their involvement and permission.
We also know that there have been some questions about our role. We have offered assistance to efforts led by the Black Cultural Zone and other organizations in whatever way is useful.

Dear Neighbors: Thanks to so many of you who have reached out to encourage the Museum‚Äôs involvement in preserving, documenting, and archiving the artwork in Oakland made as part of protests and as an expression of the Movement for Black Lives.

https://t.co/xHX4lqQLQU
- The Friday Nights at OMCA Team

Friday Nights at OMCA pauses for the people tonight, in respect for our community and staff's call for reflection and action, be it by pen or by protests on the streets at home and around the world. Another staff playlist is queued up for your enjoyment next week. Be safe.

We are exploring ways for OMCA to respond, continue the vital work of equity & inclusion, & ensure we give voice to the cry for an end to violence against black people, people of color, & other brothers, sisters, & siblings who feel the impact of marginalization & inhumanity.
Our staff is currently sharing resources, support, and ways to take action. We're including a few links to those resources on our blog. https://t.co/Tg0dnK4Wqz
OMCA stands united against injustice. We remain committed to fighting injustice and elevating resources to help end racism in America. We believe Black Lives Matter.
Got an idea for future cards? Email us at takeaction @ museumca dot org
